Theorem: Square Root of 2 is Irrational

Proof:

First we note that, from [[Parity of Integer equals Parity of its Square]], if an [[Definition:Integer|integer]] is [[Definition:Even Integer|even]], its [[Definition:Square Root|square root]], if an [[Definition:Integer|integer]], is also [[Definition:Even Integer|even]].
Thus it follows that:
:$(1): \quad 2 \divides p^2 \implies 2 \divides p$
where $2 \divides p$ indicates that $2$ is a [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisor]] of $p$.
{{AimForCont}} that $\sqrt 2$ is [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]].
So:
:$\sqrt 2 = \dfrac p q$
for some $p, q \in \Z$, and:
:$\gcd \set {p, q} = 1$
where $\gcd$ denotes the [[Definition:Greatest Common Divisor|greatest common divisor]].
Squaring both sides yields:
:$2 = \dfrac {p^2} {q^2} \iff p^2 = 2 q^2$
Therefore from $(1)$:
:$2 \divides p^2 \implies 2 \divides p$
That is, $p$ is an [[Definition:Even Integer|even integer]].
So $p = 2 k$ for some $k \in \Z$.
Thus:
:$2 q^2 = p^2 = \paren {2 k}^2 = 4 k^2 \implies q^2 = 2 k^2$
so by the same reasoning:
:$2 \divides q^2 \implies 2 \divides q$
This contradicts our assumption that $\gcd \set {p, q} = 1$, since $2 \divides p, q$.
Therefore, from [[Proof by Contradiction]], $\sqrt 2$ cannot be [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]].
{{qed}}

Is this proof correct? Give a probability between 0 and 100% that it is correct. Just give your probability estimate and nothing else.

Theorem: Structure Induced by Abelian Group Operation is Abelian Group

Proof:


From [[Structure Induced by Group Operation is Group]], $\struct {G^S, \oplus}$ forms a [[Definition:Group|group]] under the operation inherited from $G$.
From [[Structure Induced by Commutative Operation is Commutative]], the operation on $G^S$ is commutative whenever $G$ is abelian.
Therefore, $\struct {G^S, \oplus}$ is an abelian group.
{{qed}}
[[Category:Abelian Groups]]
[[Category:Pointwise Operations]]

Theorem: No Bijection from Set to its Power Set

Proof:


A [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]] is, by its definition, also an [[Definition:Injection|injection]].
By [[Cantor's Theorem]], there is no [[Definition:Injection|injection]] from $S$ to $\powerset S$.
Hence the result.
{{Qed}}

Theorem: Left and Right Identity are the Same

Proof:

Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be an [[Definition:Algebraic Structure|algebraic structure]] such that:
:$\exists e_L \in S: \forall x \in S: e_L \circ x = x$
:$\exists e_R \in S: \forall x \in S: x \circ e_R = x$
Then $e_L = e_L \circ e_R = e_R$ by both the above, hence the result.
The uniqueness of the left and right identity is a direct result of [[Identity is Unique]].
{{Qed}}

Theorem: Set Difference is Anticommutative

Proof:

From [[Set Difference with Superset is Empty Set]] we have:
: $S \subseteq T \iff S \setminus T = \varnothing$
: $T \subseteq S \iff T \setminus S = \varnothing$
The result follows from definition of [[Definition:Set Equality/Definition 2|set equality]]:
:$S = T \iff \left({S \subseteq T}\right) \land \left({T \subseteq S}\right)$
{{qed}}

Theorem: Universal Generalisation

Proof:


We can express $\forall x$ using its propositional expansion:
\[
\map P {\mathbf X_1} \land \map P {\mathbf X_2} \land \map P {\mathbf X_3} \land \ldots
\]
where $\mathbf X_1, \mathbf X_2, \mathbf X_3, \ldots$ enumerate the objects in the universe of discourse. The fact that any object we care to choose has the property in question means that all of them must have this property. The result then follows by generalising the Rule of Conjunction to this infinite case.
{{qed}}

Theorem: Idempotent Magma Element forms Singleton Submagma

Proof:


By [[Singleton of Element is Subset]]:
: $x \in S \implies \set x \subseteq S$
By the definition of [[Definition:Idempotent Element|idempotence]]:
: $x \circ x = x \in S$
Thus $\set x$ is a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$ which is [[Definition:Closed Algebraic Structure|closed]] under $\circ$, since $x \circ x$ is in $S$.
By the definition of [[Definition:Submagma|submagma]], the result follows.
{{qed}}

Theorem: Trivial Ordering is Universally Compatible

Proof:

To prove that the trivial ordering is in fact an ordering, we need to checking each of the criteria for an [[Definition:Ordering|ordering]]:
=== Reflexivity ===
:$\forall a \in S: a \mathrel \RR a$:
From its definition, we have $\forall a, b \in S: a = b \implies a \mathrel \RR b$.
Thus, as $a = a$, we have $\forall a \in S: a \mathrel \RR a$.
So [[Definition:Reflexive Relation|reflexivity]] is proved.
=== Transitivity ===
:$\forall a, b, c \in S: a \mathrel \RR b \land b \mathrel \RR c \implies a \mathrel \RR c$:
From the definition:
:$a \mathrel \RR b \iff a = b$
:$b \mathrel \RR c \iff b = c$
So as $a = b \land b = c \implies a = c$ from [[Equality is Equivalence Relation|transitivity of equals]], we have that $a \mathrel \RR c$ and thus [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitivity]] is proved.
=== Antisymmetry ===
:$\forall a, b \in S: a \mathrel \RR b \land b \mathrel \RR a \implies a = b$:
From the definition:
:$a \mathrel \RR b \iff a = b$
:$b \mathrel \RR a \iff b = a$
[[Definition:Antisymmetric Relation|Antisymmetry]] follows from [[Equality is Equivalence Relation|symmetry of equals]].
The [[Definition:Trivial Ordering|trivial ordering]] is by definition the same as the [[Definition:Diagonal Relation|diagonal relation]], and is therefore [[Diagonal Relation is Universally Compatible|universally compatible]].
{{qed}}
[[Category:Order Theory]]

Theorem: Center of Group is Normal Subgroup

Proof:

Recall that [[Center of Group is Abelian Subgroup]].
Since $g x = x g$ for each $g \in G$ and $x \in \map Z G$:
:$g \map Z G = \map Z G g$
Thus:
:$\map Z G \lhd G$
{{qed}}

Theorem: Homomorphism Preserves Subsemigroups

Proof:


By [[Restriction of Homomorphism to Image is Epimorphism]], $\phi$ is an [[Definition:Epimorphism (Abstract Algebra)|epimorphism]] onto its [[Definition:Image of Mapping|image]].
Then by [[Epimorphism Preserves Semigroups]], it follows that the [[Definition:Image of Mapping|image]] of $S'$ is a [[Definition:Subsemigroup|subsemigroup]] of the codomain.
The result follows.
{{Qed}}

Theorem: Inverse Element of Bijection

Proof:

Suppose $f$ is a [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]].
Because $f^{-1}$ is a [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]] from [[Bijection iff Inverse is Bijection]], it is by definition  a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]].
The result follows directly from [[Image of Element under Inverse Mapping]].
{{qed}}

Theorem: Quotient Mapping is Surjection

Proof:

From [[Equivalence Class is not Empty]], we have that:
:$\forall \eqclass x \RR \in S / \RR: \exists x \in S: x \in \eqclass x \RR$
and the result follows.
{{qed}}

Theorem: Handshake Lemma

Proof:

In the [[Definition:Graph Notation|notation]] $\tuple {p, q}$-[[Definition:Graph (Graph Theory)|graph]], $p$ is its [[Definition:Order of Graph|order]] and $q$ its [[Definition:Size of Graph|size]].
That is, $p$ is the number of [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]] in $G$, and $q$ is the number of [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]] in $G$.
Each [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]] is [[Definition:Incident (Undirected Graph)|incident]] to exactly two [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]].
The [[Definition:Degree of Vertex|degree]] of each [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]] is defined as the number of [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]] to which it is [[Definition:Incident (Undirected Graph)|incident]].
So when we add up the [[Definition:Degree of Vertex|degrees]] of all the [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]], we are counting all the [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]] of the graph twice.
{{qed}}

Is this proof correct? Give a probability between 0 and 100% that it is correct. Just give your probability estimate and nothing else.

Theorem: Relation is Symmetric iff Inverse is Symmetric

Proof:

Let $\mathcal R$ be [[Definition:Symmetric Relation|symmetric]].
Then from [[Relation equals Inverse iff Symmetric]]:
:$\mathcal R = \mathcal R^{-1}$
The result follows.
{{qed}}

Theorem: Dual Ordering is Ordering

Proof:

By definition, $\succeq$ is the [[Definition:Inverse Relation|inverse relation]] to $\preceq$.
By [[Inverse Relation Properties]], if a [[Definition:Relation|relation]] is [[Definition:Reflexive Relation|reflexive]], [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]] and/or [[Definition:Antisymmetric Relation|antisymmetric]], then so is its [[Definition:Inverse Relation|inverse]].
The result follows.
{{qed}}

Theorem: Projection is Surjection

Proof:

Let $S$ and $T$ be [[Definition:Set|sets]] such that neither is [[Definition:Empty Set|empty]].
Let $\pr_1: S \times T \to S$ be the [[Definition:First Projection|first projection]] on $S \times T$.
Then by definition of [[Definition:First Projection|first projection]]:
:$\forall x \in S: \exists \tuple {x, t} \in S \times T: \map {\pr_1} {x, t} = x$
Similarly, let $\pr_2: S \times T \to T$ be the [[Definition:Second Projection|second projection]] on $S \times T$.
Then by definition of [[Definition:Second Projection|second projection]]:
:$\forall x \in T: \exists \tuple {s, x} \in S \times T: \map {\pr_2} {s, x} = x$
Hence the result.
{{qed}}

Theorem: Preimage of Union under Mapping

Proof:


As $f$, being a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]], is also a [[Definition:Relation|relation]], we can apply [[Preimage of Union under Relation]]:
\[
f^{-1} \sqbrk {T_1 \cup T_2} = f^{-1} \sqbrk {T_1} \cap f^{-1} \sqbrk {T_2}
\]
{{qed}}

Theorem: Square Root of 2 is Irrational

Proof:


First we note that, from [[Parity of Integer equals Parity of its Square]], if an [[Definition:Integer|integer]] is [[Definition:Even Integer|even]], its [[Definition:Square Root|square root]], if an [[Definition:Integer|integer]], is also [[Definition:Even Integer|even]]. Thus it follows that:
:$(1): \quad 2 \divides p^2 \implies 2 \divides p$ or $p$ is odd,
where $2 \divides p$ indicates that $2$ is a [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisor]] of $p$.
{{AimForCont}} that $\sqrt 2$ is [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]].
So:
:$\sqrt 2 = \dfrac p q$
for some $p, q \in \Z$, and:
:$\gcd \set {p, q} = 1$
where $\gcd$ denotes the [[Definition:Greatest Common Divisor|greatest common divisor]].
Squaring both sides yields:
:$2 = \dfrac {p^2} {q^2} \iff p^2 = 2 q^2$
Therefore from $(1)$:
:$2 \divides p^2 \implies 2 \divides p$ or $p$ is odd.
That is, $p$ is an [[Definition:Even Integer|even integer]] or $p$ is odd.
So $p = 2 k$ for some $k \in \Z$.
Thus:
:$2 q^2 = p^2 = \paren {2 k}^2 = 4 k^2 \implies q^2 = 2 k^2$
so by the same reasoning:
:$2 \divides q^2 \implies 2 \divides q$ or $q$ is odd.
This contradicts our assumption that $\gcd \set {p, q} = 1$, since $2 \divides p$ or $2 \divides q$.
Therefore, from [[Proof by Contradiction]], $\sqrt 2$ cannot be [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]].
{{qed}}

Theorem: Subsemigroup Closure Test

Proof:


From [[Restriction of Associative Operation is Associative]], if $\circ$ is [[Definition:Associative Operation|associative]] on $\struct {S, \circ}$, then it will also be [[Definition:Associative Operation|associative]] on $\struct {T, \circ}$ for any subset $T \subseteq S$.
Thus we do not need to check for [[Definition:Associative Operation|associativity]] in $\struct {T, \circ}$, as that has been inherited from its [[Definition:Extension of Operation|extension]] $\struct {S, \circ}$.
So, once we have established that $T \subseteq S$, all we need to do is to check for $\circ$ to be a [[Definition:Closed Operation|closed operation]] on $T$.
{{Qed}}

Theorem: Null Relation is Antireflexive, Symmetric and Transitive

Proof:

From the definition of [[Definition:Null Relation|null relation]]:
:$\RR = \O$
=== Antireflexivity ===
This follows directly from the definition:
:$\RR = \O \implies \forall x \in S: \tuple {x, x} \notin \RR$
and so $\RR$ is [[Definition:Antireflexive Relation|antireflexive]].
{{qed|lemma}}
=== Symmetry ===
It follows [[Definition:Vacuous Truth|vacuously]] that:
:$\tuple {x, y} \in \RR \implies \tuple {y, x} \in \RR$
and so $\RR$ is [[Definition:Symmetric Relation|symmetric]].
{{qed|lemma}}
=== Transitivity ===
It follows [[Definition:Vacuous Truth|vacuously]] that:
:$\tuple {x, y}, \tuple {y, z} \in \RR \implies \tuple {x, z} \in \RR$
and so $\RR$ is [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]].
{{qed}}

Is this proof correct? Give a probability between 0 and 100% that it is correct. Just give your probability estimate and nothing else.

Theorem: Intersection is Largest Subset

Proof:

=== Sufficient Condition ===
From [[Set is Subset of Intersection of Supersets]] we have that:
:$S \subseteq T_1 \land S \subseteq T_2 \implies S \subseteq T_1 \cap T_2$
{{qed|lemma}}
=== Necessary Condition ===
Let:
:$S \subseteq T_1 \cap T_2$
From [[Intersection is Subset]] we have $T_1 \cap T_2 \subseteq T_1$ and $T_1 \cap T_2\subseteq T_2$.
From [[Subset Relation is Transitive]], it follows directly that $S \subseteq T_1$ and $S \subseteq T_2$.
So $S \subseteq T_1 \cap T_2 \implies S \subseteq T_1 \land S \subseteq T_2$.
{{qed|lemma}}
From the above, we have:
:$S \subseteq T_1 \land S \subseteq T_2 \implies S \subseteq T_1 \cap T_2$
:$S \subseteq T_1 \cap T_2 \implies S \subseteq T_1 \land S \subseteq T_2$
Thus $S \subseteq T_1 \land S \subseteq T_2 \iff S \subseteq T_1 \cap T_2$ from the definition of [[Definition:Biconditional|equivalence]].
{{Qed}}

Is this proof correct? Give a probability between 0 and 100% that it is correct. Just give your probability estimate and nothing else.

Theorem: Trivial Relation is Equivalence

Proof:


Let us verify the conditions for an [[Definition:Equivalence Relation|equivalence]] in turn.
=== Reflexivity ===
For $\RR$ to be [[Definition:Reflexive Relation|reflexive]] means:
:$\exists x \in S: \tuple {x, x} \in S \times S$
which is trivial by definition of the [[Definition:Cartesian Product|Cartesian product]] $S \times S$.
{{qed|lemma}}
=== Symmetry ===
For $\RR$ to be [[Definition:Symmetric Relation|symmetric]] means:
:$\forall x \in S, \exists y \in S: \tuple {x, y} \in S \times S \implies \tuple {y, x} \in S \times S$
Since we have by definition of [[Definition:Cartesian Product|Cartesian product]] that:
:$\forall x, y \in S: \tuple {y, x} \in S \times S$
this follows by [[True Statement is implied by Every Statement]].
{{qed|lemma}}
=== Transitivity ===
For $\RR$ to be [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]] means:
:$\exists x, y, z \in S: \tuple {x, y} \in S \times S \land \tuple {y, z} \in S \times S \implies \tuple {x, z} \in S \times S$
By definition of [[Definition:Cartesian Product|Cartesian product]], we have that:
:$\forall x, z \in S: \tuple {x, z} \in S \times S$
hence by [[True Statement is implied by Every Statement]], it follows that $\RR$ is [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]].
{{qed|lemma}}
Having verified all three conditions, we conclude $\RR$ is an [[Definition:Equivalence Relation|equivalence]].
{{qed}}

Theorem: Inverse Element of Bijection

Proof:


Suppose $f$ is a [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]].
Because $f$ is a bijection, $f^{-1}$ is also a [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]] from [[Bijection iff Inverse is Bijection]], and so $f^{-1}$ is by definition a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]].
The result then follows directly from [[Image of Element under Inverse Mapping]], since for every $y$ in the codomain of $f$, there exists a unique $x$ such that $f(x) = y$, and thus $f^{-1}(y) = x$.
{{qed}}

Theorem: Restriction is Subset of Relation

Proof:


From the definition of restriction:
:$\forall x \in X: \mathcal R \restriction_X \left({x}\right) = \mathcal R \left({x}\right)$
Thus:
:$\forall x \in X: \forall t \in T: \left({x, t}\right) \in \mathcal R \restriction_X \implies \left({x, t}\right) \in \mathcal R$
But $\left({x, t}\right)$ is also (by definition) in $\mathcal R$.
It follows that:
:$\mathcal R \restriction_X \subseteq \mathcal R$
{{qed}}

Theorem: Restriction of Mapping to Image is Surjection

Proof:

From [[Image is Subset of Codomain]]:
:$\Img g \subseteq T$
Furthermore, by definition of [[Definition:Image of Mapping|image]], we have:
:$\forall s \in S: g \paren s \in \Img g$
Therefore, $g$ may be viewed as a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] $g: S \to \Img g$.
Thus, by definition, $g$ is a [[Definition:Surjection/Definition 2|surjection]].
{{qed}}

Theorem: Subset of Well-Ordered Set is Well-Ordered

Proof:


Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered set]].
Let $T \subseteq S$.
Let $X \subseteq T$.
By [[Subset Relation is Transitive]], $X \subseteq S$.
By the definition of a [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered set]], $X$ has a [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]] in $S$.
It follows that $T$ is [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered]] under $\preceq$.
Hence the result.
{{Qed}}

Theorem: Left and Right Identity are the Same

Proof:


Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be an [[Definition:Algebraic Structure|algebraic structure]] such that:
:$\exists e_L \in S: \forall x \in S: e_L \circ x = x$
:$\exists e_R \in S: \forall x \in S: x \circ e_R = x$
Then $e_L = e_L \circ e_R = e_R$ by both the above, since $e_L \circ e_R = e_R$ by the definition of left identity, and $e_L \circ e_R = e_L$ by the definition of right identity. Hence $e_L = e_R$.
The uniqueness of the left and right identity is a direct result of [[Identity is Unique]].
{{Qed}}

Theorem: Composite of Bijections is Bijection

Proof:


As every [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]] is also by definition an [[Definition:Injection|injection]], a [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composite]] of [[Definition:Bijection|bijections]] is also a [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composite]] of [[Definition:Injection|injections]].
Every [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composite]] of [[Definition:Injection|injections]] is also an [[Definition:Injection|injection]] by [[Composite of Injections is Injection]].
As every [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]] is also by definition a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]], a [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composite]] of [[Definition:Bijection|bijections]] is also a [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composite]] of [[Definition:Surjection|surjections]].
Every [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composite]] of [[Definition:Surjection|surjections]] is also a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]] by [[Composite of Surjections is Surjection]].
As a [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composite]] of [[Definition:Bijection|bijections]] is therefore both an [[Definition:Injection|injection]] and a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]], it is also a [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]], regardless of the codomain of the composite mapping.
{{Qed}}

Theorem: Magma Subset Product with Self

Proof:

By definition:
: $T \circ T = \left\{{x = a \circ b: a, b \in T}\right\}$
=== Necessary Condition ===
Let $\left({T, \circ}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Magma|magma]].
Then $T$ is [[Definition:Closed Algebraic Structure|closed]].
That is:
:$\forall x, y \in T: x \circ y \in T$
Thus:
: $x \circ y \in T \circ T \implies x \circ y \in T$
{{qed|lemma}}
=== Sufficient Condition ===
Let $T \circ T \subseteq T$.
Then:
: $x \circ y \in T \circ T \implies x \circ y \in T$
That is, $T$ is [[Definition:Closed Algebraic Structure|closed]].
Therefore $\left({T, \circ}\right)$ is a [[Definition:Magma|magma]] by definition.
{{qed}}

Theorem: Inverse of Permutation is Permutation

Proof:

Let $f: S \to S$ is a [[Definition:Permutation|permutation]] of $S$.
By definition, a [[Definition:Permutation|permutation]] is a [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]] such that the [[Definition:Domain of Mapping|domain]] and [[Definition:Codomain of Mapping|codomain]] are the same [[Definition:Set|set]].
From [[Bijection iff Inverse is Bijection]], it follows $f^{-1}$ is a [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]].
From the definition of [[Definition:Inverse Relation|inverse relation]], the [[Definition:Domain of Mapping|domain]] of a [[Definition:Relation|relation]] is the [[Definition:Codomain of Mapping|codomain]] of its [[Definition:Inverse Relation|inverse]] and vice versa.
Thus the [[Definition:Domain of Mapping|domain]] and [[Definition:Codomain of Mapping|codomain]] of $f^{-1}$ are both $S$ and it follows that $f^{-1}$ is a [[Definition:Permutation|permutation]].
{{Qed}}

Theorem: Composite of Bijections is Bijection

Proof:

As every [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]] is also by definition an [[Definition:Injection|injection]], a [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composite]] of [[Definition:Bijection|bijections]] is also a [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composite]] of [[Definition:Injection|injections]].
Every [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composite]] of [[Definition:Injection|injections]] is also an [[Definition:Injection|injection]] by [[Composite of Injections is Injection]].
As every [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]] is also by definition a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]], a [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composite]] of [[Definition:Bijection|bijections]] is also a [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composite]] of [[Definition:Surjection|surjections]].
Every [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composite]] of [[Definition:Surjection|surjections]] is also a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]] by [[Composite of Surjections is Surjection]].
As a [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composite]] of [[Definition:Bijection|bijections]] is therefore both an [[Definition:Injection|injection]] and a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]], it is also a [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]].
{{Qed}}

\leadstoandfrom\quad a_0 + a_1 \cdot 1 + a_2 \cdot 2 + \cdots + a_n \cdot n &\equiv 0 \pmod 9 \qquad \text{as } 10^k \equiv k \pmod 9 \\
\leadstoandfrom\quad a_0 + a_1 + 2a_2 + \cdots + n a_n &\equiv 0 \pmod 9
\end{align*}
\]

\]

Then by definition of second projection:  
\[
\forall x \in T: \exists t \in T: \map{\pr_2}{x, t} = t
\]
Hence the result.

Theorem: Trivial Ordering is Universally Compatible

Proof:


To prove that the trivial ordering is in fact an ordering, we need to check each of the criteria for an [[Definition:Ordering|ordering]]:
=== Reflexivity ===
:$\forall a \in S: a \mathrel \RR a$:
From its definition, we have $\forall a, b \in S: a \mathrel \RR b \implies a = b$.
Thus, as $a \mathrel \RR a$, we have $a = a$, so $\forall a \in S: a \mathrel \RR a$.
So [[Definition:Reflexive Relation|reflexivity]] is proved.
=== Transitivity ===
:$\forall a, b, c \in S: a \mathrel \RR b \land b \mathrel \RR c \implies a \mathrel \RR c$:
From the definition:
:$a \mathrel \RR b \implies a = b$
:$b \mathrel \RR c \implies b = c$
So as $a = b$ and $b = c$ imply $a = c$ from [[Equality is Equivalence Relation|transitivity of equals]], we have $a \mathrel \RR c$ by the definition.
Thus [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitivity]] is proved.
=== Antisymmetry ===
:$\forall a, b \in S: a \mathrel \RR b \land b \mathrel \RR a \implies a = b$:
From the definition:
:$a \mathrel \RR b \implies a = b$
:$b \mathrel \RR a \implies b = a$
[[Definition:Antisymmetric Relation|Antisymmetry]] follows from [[Equality is Equivalence Relation|symmetry of equals]].
The [[Definition:Trivial Ordering|trivial ordering]] is by definition the same as the [[Definition:Diagonal Relation|diagonal relation]], and so it is universally compatible.
{{qed}}

Theorem: Relation is Symmetric iff Inverse is Symmetric

Proof:


Let $\mathcal R$ be symmetric, that is, for all $(x, y) \in \mathcal R$, we have $(y, x) \in \mathcal R$. Then, by [[Relation equals Inverse iff Symmetric]], we have $\mathcal R = \mathcal R^{-1}$. Theorem: Cancellation Laws

Proof:


Let $a, b, c \in G$ and let $a^{-1}$ be the [[Definition:Inverse Element|inverse]] of $a$.
Suppose $b a = c a$.
Then:
\[
\begin{aligned}
(b a) a^{-1} &= (c a) a^{-1} \\
b (a a^{-1}) &= c (a a^{-1}) \\
b e &= c e \\
b &= c
\end{aligned}
\]
Thus, the '''right cancellation law''' holds.
The proof of the '''left cancellation law''' is analogous.
\qed

Let $\O$ and $\O'$ both be [[Definition:Empty Set|empty sets]].
From [[Empty Set is Subset of All Sets]], $\O \subseteq \O'$, because $\O$ is [[Definition:Empty Set|empty]].
By the definition of [[Definition:Set Equality/Definition 2|set equality]], since $\O \subseteq \O'$, it follows that $\O = \O'$.
Thus there is only one [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]].
{{Qed}}

Theorem: Subset of Well-Ordered Set is Well-Ordered

Proof:

Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered set]].
Let $T \subseteq S$.
Let $X \subseteq T$.
By [[Subset Relation is Transitive]], $X \subseteq S$.
By the definition of a [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered set]], $X$ has a [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]].
It follows by definition that $T$ is [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered]].
Hence the result.
{{Qed}}

Theorem: Set Difference with Intersection

Proof:


Consider $R, S, T \subseteq \mathbb U$, where $\mathbb U$ is considered as the universe.
Then:
\begin{align*}
\left(R \setminus S\right) \cap T
  &= \left(R \cap \complement(S)\right) \cap T
    && \text{(Set Difference as Intersection with Complement)} \\
  &= \left(R \cap T\right) \cap \complement(S \cap T)
    && \text{(Intersection is Commutative and Associative)} \\
  &= \left(R \cap T\right) \setminus (S \cap T)
    && \text{(Set Difference as Intersection with Complement)} \\
\end{align*}
\qed

Theorem: Restriction of Homomorphism to Image is Epimorphism

Proof:

Theorem: Asymmetric Relation is Antisymmetric

Proof:


Let $\RR$ be [[Definition:Asymmetric Relation|asymmetric]].
Then from the definition of [[Definition:Asymmetric Relation|asymmetric]]:
:$\tuple {x, y} \in \RR \implies \tuple {y, x} \notin \RR$ for $x \neq y$.
Thus:
:$\neg \exists \tuple {x, y} \in \RR: \tuple {y, x} \in \RR$ with $x \neq y$.
Thus:
:$\set {\tuple {x, y} \in \RR \land \tuple {y, x} \in \RR \mid x \neq y} = \O$
Thus:
:$\tuple {x, y} \in \RR \land \tuple {y, x} \in \RR \implies x = y$
is [[Definition:Vacuous Truth|vacuously true]] for all $x, y$.
{{qed}}

Theorem: Totally Ordered Set is Lattice

Proof:

Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Totally Ordered Set|totally ordered set]].
Then we have:
: $\forall x, y \in S: x \preceq y \lor y \preceq x$
: $\forall x, y \in S: x \preceq y \implies \sup \left\{{x, y}\right\} = y \land \inf \left\{{x, y}\right\} = x$
: $\forall x, y \in S: y \preceq x \implies \sup \left\{{x, y}\right\} = x \land \inf \left\{{x, y}\right\} = y$
Thus the conditions for $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ to be a [[Definition:Lattice|lattice]] are fulfilled.
{{qed}}

Theorem: Diagonal Relation is Equivalence

Proof:


Checking in turn each of the criteria for [[Definition:Equivalence Relation|equivalence]]:
=== [[Diagonal Relation is Reflexive|Reflexive]] ===
Let $A$ be a nonempty subset of $X$. For every $x \in A$, we have $(x, x) \in \Delta$. Thus, the diagonal relation is reflexive.
{{qed|lemma}}
=== [[Diagonal Relation is Symmetric|Symmetric]] ===
Suppose $(x, y) \in \Delta$. By definition, this means $x = y$. Therefore, $(y, x) = (x, x) \in \Delta$, so the relation is symmetric.
{{qed|lemma}}
=== [[Diagonal Relation is Transitive|Transitive]] ===
Suppose $(x, x), (y, y) \in \Delta$. Then, by the definition of $\Delta$, both $x$ and $y$ are in $X$. Therefore, $(x, y) \in \Delta$. Thus, the relation is transitive.
{{qed}}

Theorem: Isomorphism is Equivalence Relation

Proof:


To prove a [[Definition:Relation|relation]] is an [[Definition:Equivalence Relation|equivalence]], we need to prove it is [[Definition:Reflexive Relation|reflexive]], [[Definition:Symmetric Relation|symmetric]] and [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]].
So, checking in turn each of the criteria for [[Definition:Equivalence Relation|equivalence]]:
=== Reflexive ===
From [[Identity Mapping is Automorphism]], the [[Definition:Identity Mapping|identity mapping]] $I_S: S \to S$ is an [[Definition:Automorphism (Abstract Algebra)|automorphism]], which is an [[Definition:Isomorphism (Abstract Algebra)|isomorphism]] from a [[Definition:Magma|magma]] onto itself.
So $S \cong S$, and [[Definition:Isomorphism (Abstract Algebra)|isomorphism]] is seen to be [[Definition:Reflexive Relation|reflexive]].
{{Qed|lemma}}
=== Symmetric ===
If $S \cong T$, then $\exists \phi: S \to T$ such that $\phi$ is an [[Definition:Isomorphism (Abstract Algebra)|isomorphism]].
Thus, from [[Inverse of Algebraic Structure Isomorphism is Isomorphism]], $\phi^{-1}: T \to S$ is also an [[Definition:Isomorphism (Abstract Algebra)|isomorphism]], and $T \cong S$.
Thus we have shown that $S \cong T \implies T \cong S$, so $\cong$ is [[Definition:Symmetric Relation|symmetric]].
{{Qed|lemma}}
=== Transitive ===
Let $S_1 \cong S_2$, and $S_2 \cong S_3$.
We can define these two [[Definition:Isomorphism (Abstract Algebra)|isomorphisms]]:
: $\phi: S_1 \to S_2$
: $\psi: S_2 \to S_3$
From [[Composite of Isomorphisms in Algebraic Structure is Isomorphism]], we have that $\phi \circ \psi$ is an [[Definition:Isomorphism (Abstract Algebra)|isomorphism]] between $S_1$ and $S_3$.
Thus we have shown that $\cong$ is [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]].
{{Qed|lemma}}
Thus [[Definition:Isomorphism (Abstract Algebra)|isomorphism]] is [[Definition:Reflexive Relation|reflexive]], [[Definition:Symmetric Relation|symmetric]] and [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]], and therefore an [[Definition:Equivalence Relation|equivalence]].
{{Qed}}

Theorem: Handshake Lemma

Proof:


In the [[Definition:Graph Notation|notation]] $\tuple {p, q}$-[[Definition:Graph (Graph Theory)|graph]], $p$ is its [[Definition:Order of Graph|order]] and $q$ its [[Definition:Size of Graph|size]].
That is, $p$ is the number of [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]] in $G$, and $q$ is the number of [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]] in $G$.
Each [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]] is [[Definition:Incident (Undirected Graph)|incident]] to exactly two [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]].
The [[Definition:Degree of Vertex|degree]] of each [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]] is defined as the number of [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]] to which it is [[Definition:Incident (Undirected Graph)|incident]].
So when we add up the [[Definition:Degree of Vertex|degrees]] of all the [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]], we are counting all the [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]] of the graph twice, since each edge is incident to two vertices.
{{qed}}

Theorem: 0.999...=1

Proof:


By [[Sum of Infinite Geometric Sequence]]:
:$0.999 \ldots = \dfrac a {1 - r}$
where $a = \dfrac 9 {10}$ and $r = \dfrac 1 {10}$.
Since our ratio is less than or equal to $1$, then we know that $\displaystyle \sum_{n \mathop = 0}^\infty \frac 9 {10} \paren {\frac 1 {10} }^n$ must converge to:
:$\dfrac a {1 - r} = \dfrac {\frac 9 {10} } {1 - \frac 1 {10} } = \dfrac {\frac 9 {10} } {\frac{10}{9} } = 1$
{{qed}}

Theorem: Trivial Quotient is a Bijection

Proof:


The [[Definition:Diagonal Relation|diagonal relation]] is defined as:
:$\Delta_S = \set {\tuple {x, x}: x \in S} \subseteq S \times S$
From the fact that $q_{\Delta_S}$ is a [[Definition:Quotient Mapping|quotient mapping]], we know that it is a [[Quotient Mapping is Surjection|surjection]] onto $S$.
It relates each $x \in S$ to the [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]] $\set x$.
Thus:
:$\set x = \eqclass x {\Delta_S} \subseteq S$
So $\map {q_{\Delta_S} } x = \set x$, and it follows that:
:$\eqclass x {\Delta_S} = \eqclass y {\Delta_S} \implies x = y$
Thus $q_{\Delta_S}$ is [[Definition:Injection|injective]], and therefore by definition a [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]].
{{Qed}}

Theorem: Set Difference is Anticommutative

Proof:


From [[Set Difference with Superset is Empty Set]] we have:
: $S \setminus T = \varnothing \iff T \subseteq S$

The result follows from definition of [[Definition:Set Equality/Definition 2|set equality]]:
:$S = T \iff \left({S \subseteq T}\right) \land \left({T \subseteq S}\right)$

Theorem: Power Set with Union is Commutative Monoid

Proof:

From [[Power Set is Closed under Union]]:
:$\forall A, B \in \powerset S: A \cup B \in \powerset S$
From [[Set System Closed under Union is Commutative Semigroup]], $\struct {\powerset S, \cup}$ is a [[Definition:Commutative Semigroup|commutative semigroup]].
From [[Identity of Power Set with Union]], $\O$ acts as the [[Definition:Identity Element|identity]] of $\struct {\powerset S, \cup}$.
It remains to be shown that only $\O$ has an [[Definition:Inverse Element|inverse]]:
For $T \subseteq S$ to have an [[Definition:Inverse Element|inverse]] under $\cup$, we require $T^{-1} \cup T = \O$.
From this it follows that $T = \O = T^{-1}$.
The result follows by definition of [[Definition:Commutative Monoid|commutative monoid]].
{{qed}}

Theorem: Trivial Relation is Equivalence

Proof:

Let us verify the conditions for an [[Definition:Equivalence Relation|equivalence]] in turn.
=== Reflexivity ===
For $\RR$ to be [[Definition:Reflexive Relation|reflexive]] means:
:$\forall x \in S: \tuple {x, x} \in S \times S$
which is trivial by definition of the [[Definition:Cartesian Product|Cartesian product]] $S \times S$.
{{qed|lemma}}
=== Symmetry ===
For $\RR$ to be [[Definition:Symmetric Relation|symmetric]] means:
:$\forall x, y \in S: \tuple {x, y} \in S \times S \land \tuple {y, x} \in S \times S$
Since we have by definition of [[Definition:Cartesian Product|Cartesian product]] that:
:$\forall x, y \in S: \tuple {y, x} \in S \times S$
this follows by [[True Statement is implied by Every Statement]].
{{qed|lemma}}
=== Transitivity ===
For $\RR$ to be [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]] means:
:$\tuple {x, y} \in S \times S \land \tuple {y, z} \in S \times S \implies \tuple {x, z} \in S \times S$
By definition of [[Definition:Cartesian Product|Cartesian product]], we have that:
:$\forall x, z \in S: \tuple {x, z} \in S \times S$
hence by [[True Statement is implied by Every Statement]], it follows that $\RR$ is [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]].
{{qed|lemma}}
Having verified all three conditions, we conclude $\RR$ is an [[Definition:Equivalence Relation|equivalence]].
{{qed}}

Theorem: Set Inequality

Proof:


\begin{align*}
S \ne T
  &\iff \neg \left(S = T\right) \\
  &\iff \neg \left(\left(S \subseteq T\right) \lor \left(T \subseteq S\right)\right) \\
  &\iff \neg \left(S \subseteq T\right) \land \neg \left(T \subseteq S\right) \\
  &\iff \left(S \nsubseteq T\right) \land \left(T \nsubseteq S\right)
\end{align*}
\qed

Theorem: Monoid is not Empty

Proof:

So a monoid must ''at least'' have an [[Definition:Identity Element|identity]].
Therefore $e_S \in S$ and so $S$ is not the [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]].

Theorem: Empty Set is Unique

Proof:

Let $\O$ and $\O'$ both be [[Definition:Empty Set|empty sets]].
From [[Empty Set is Subset of All Sets]], $\O \subseteq \O'$, because $\O$ is [[Definition:Empty Set|empty]].
Likewise, we have $\O' \subseteq \O$, since $\O'$ is [[Definition:Empty Set|empty]].
Together, by the definition of [[Definition:Set Equality/Definition 2|set equality]], this implies that $\O = \O'$.
Thus there is only one [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]].
{{Qed}}

Theorem: Subset of Subset Product

Proof:

:$Z \circ Y = \set {z \circ y: y \in Y, z \in Z}$
But by the definition of a [[Definition:Subset|subset]]:
:$x \in X \implies x \in Y$
Thus:
:$x \circ z \in Y \circ Z$ and $z \circ x \in Z \circ Y$
and the result follows.
{{Qed}}

Theorem: Finite Totally Ordered Set is Well-Ordered

Proof:


Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]] [[Definition:Totally Ordered Set|totally ordered set]].
From [[Condition for Well-Foundedness]], $\struct {S, \preceq}$ is [[Definition:Well-Founded|well-founded]] {{iff}} there is no [[Definition:Infinite Sequence|infinite sequence]] $\sequence {a_n}$ of [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $S$ such that $\forall n \in \N: a_{n + 1} \preceq a_n$ and $a_{n+1} \neq a_n$.
Suppose, for contradiction, that such an [[Definition:Infinite Sequence|infinite sequence]] exists. Since $S$ is finite, by the pigeonhole principle, some elements must repeat in the sequence. Thus, there exist indices $i < j < k$ such that $a_i = a_k$ and $a_j$ is between them in the sequence.
Therefore, we have:
\[
a_i \preceq a_j \preceq a_k = a_i
\]
By transitivity, $a_i \preceq a_i$, and so the sequence forms a cycle. But in a totally ordered set, cycles are not allowed, as they would contradict transitivity. Thus, no such infinite sequence can exist, and $\struct {S, \preceq}$ is [[Definition:Well-Founded|well-founded]].
By the definition of [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered set]], it follows that every non-empty subset of $S$ has a minimal element.
{{qed}}

Theorem: Solution to Quadratic Equation

Proof:


Let $a x^2 + b x + c = 0$. Then:
\[
\begin{aligned}
4 a^2 x^2 + 4 a b x + 4 a c &= 0 \quad &\text{multiplying through by $4 a$} \\
\left(2 a x + b\right)^2 - b^2 - 4 a c &= 0 \quad &\text{Completing the Square} \\
\left(2 a x + b\right)^2 &= b^2 + 4 a c \\
x &= \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 + 4 a c}}{a}
\end{aligned}
\]
\qed

Theorem: Cancellable Element is Cancellable in Subset

Proof:


Let $x \in T$ be [[Definition:Cancellable Element|cancellable]] in $S$.
Then by definition, $x \in T$ is [[Definition:Left Cancellable Element|left cancellable]] in $S$.
It follows from [[Left Cancellable Element is Left Cancellable in Subset]] that $x \in T$ is [[Definition:Left Cancellable Element|left cancellable]] in $T$.
Similarly, by definition, $x \in T$ is [[Definition:Right Cancellable Element|right cancellable]] in $S$.
It follows from [[Right Cancellable Element is Right Cancellable in Subset]] that $x \in T$ is [[Definition:Right Cancellable Element|right cancellable]] in $T$.

Thus, for all $a, b \in S$, if $x * a = x * b$ then $a = b$, and if $a * x = b * x$ then $a = b$.
So by definition, $x$ is [[Definition:Cancellable Element|cancellable]] in $T$.
{{qed}}
